question.text: The chemiosmotic coupling hypothesis of oxidative phosphorylation proposes that Adenosine Triphosphate (ATP) is formed because

options.text: High energy bonds are formed in mitochondrial proteins
ADP is pumped out of the matrix into the intermembrane space
A proton gradient forms across the inner membrane
There is a change in t of the permeability inner mitochondrial membrane toward Adenosine Diphosphate (ADP)

solution.text: The production of ATP with the help of energy liberated during oxidation of reduced coenzymes and terminal oxidation is called oxidative phosphorylation. Peter Mitchell (1961) put forward a hypothesis known as chemiosmotic hypothesis for ATP synthesis. According to this when electrons flow from duel proton, electron carrier to a non-hydrogen carrier the H<sup>+</sup> are released and expelled into the intermembrane space and thus creates a proton gradient with higher concentration of H<sup>+</sup> in the inter membranous space than the matrix. Due to proton motive force the protons flow back and energy liberated during this back flow of protons activate ATPase [present in F<sub>1</sub> head to synthesize ATP].
